text: Glycerol, a three-carbon triol (a compound with three–OH groups), can be considered a three-carbon sugar; it commonly enters catabolism as an intermediate of glycolysis.
Acetyl groups or acetate are also the breakdown products of fatty acids, amino acids, and complex aromatic plant materials such as lignin.
Microbes catabolize lipids by hydrolysis to glycerol and fatty acids (Fig.
Glucose and sugar acids are converted to pyruvate, which releases acetyl groups.
Fatty acids, more highly reduced than glycerol, acceptor is available; alternatively, they enter fermentation or anaerobic syntrophy.
The oxidation of lipid catabolites causes the rancid odor of spoiled meat or butter (issues of food microbiology, discussed in Chapter 16).
Alternatively, other pathways break down glycerol to acetate.
Carbohydrates are broken down by specific enzymes to disaccharides and then to monosaccharides such as glucose.
from sources such as milk, animal fats, and nuts.
